caption.center: RANDY CARTER, APPELLANT, vs. STATE OF MISSOURI, RESPONDENT.

court.center: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District,

opinion.opinion_text: [1] [EDITORS' NOTE: THIS OPINION IS SUBJECT TO MODIFICATION OR TRANSFER TO THE SUPREME COURT.]
opinion.posture: APPEAL FROM THE CIRCUIT COURT OF ST. LOUIS COUNTY, HONORABLE HARRY STUSSIE, JUDGE.
opinion.attorneys:
David L. Simpson, 3402 Buttonwood Dr., Columbia, MO 65201-3722, for appellant.
John Munson Morris, III, P.O. Box 899, Jefferson City, MO 65102, for respondent.
opinion.panel: Before Lawrence G. Crahan, C.J., Richard B. Teitelman, J. and Charles B. Blackmar, Sr. J.
opinion.opinion_text:
[3] Randy Carter, Movant, appeals from the judgment denying his Rule 24.035 motion for post-conviction relief. This is the second time we have addressed this case. In Carter v. State,924 S.W.2d 580 (Mo. App. E.D. 1996), this Court remanded Movant's case for the motion court to conduct an inquiry to determine if Movant's post-conviction counsel had abandoned him. Luleff v.State, 807 S.W.2d 495, 498 (Mo. banc 1991). Upon remand, a hearing was held and the motion court determined there was no abandonment by post-conviction counsel.
[4] On appeal, Movant contends the inquiry did not show sufficient compliance with Rule 24.035(e).[fn1]
[5] We have reviewed the briefs of the parties and the record on appeal and find the motion court's decision is not clearly erroneous. Rule 24.035(k). An extended opinion would have no precedential value. We affirm the judgment pursuant to Rule 84.16(b).
[fn1] In a pro se point on appeal, Movant also argues that he could not be convicted pursuant to Section 195.020, RSMo 1986 (repealed 1989) because it was repealed in 1989 after he allegedly committed the crimes. We have disregarded Movant'spro se point on appeal pursuant to Eastern District Court of Appeals Rule 380 which prohibits the filing of pro se briefs, pleadings or papers where a party is represented by counsel.
